author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Texas Abortion Law Case, a Spotlight on Brett Kavanaugh
description: If the Supreme Court is to reverse course after refusing to block the law in September, at least one conservative justice must change positions. Justice Kavanaugh is the most likely candidate.
content: WASHINGTON — Exactly two months after the Supreme Court let Texas effectively outlaw most abortions in the state, it will hear a pair of arguments on Monday that could allow it to reverse course. Much of the attention will be on Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Not Everyone in New York Wanted the Coronavirus to Lose
description: The Times reviewed intelligence reports on vaccine disinformation. Here’s what we found.
content: For nearly a year now, a small team of officials from City Hall and the public health department have pored over detailed reports about how vaccine misinformation has spread through New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Katie Rogers
title: Struggling at Home, Biden Is Buoyed by G20 Trip Abroad
description: A trip to Rome invigorated a president whose poll numbers are slumping at home, but who projected confidence in his foreign and domestic agenda.
content: ROME — President Biden capped a long weekend of diplomacy on Sunday with a swaggering proclamation of America’s renewed force on the world stage, claiming credit for what he cast as breakthroughs on climate change, tax avoidance and Iran’s nuclear ambitions at the end of a Group of 20 summit that was missing some of his biggest global adversaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Metaverse? Are You Kidding Me?!
description: Social media, in many ways, poisons our capacity to be present in the here and now.
content: Just call me an old man, a troglodyte, a Luddite, whatever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Downing
title: Jay-Z, Foo Fighters and Carole King Join the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
description: Barack Obama (via video), Paul McCartney and Taylor Swift spoke on behalf of the inductees at a ceremony that also honored Tina Turner, the Go-Go’s and Todd Rundgren.
content: CLEVELAND — Like many awards shows during the pandemic, the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame hosted a virtual induction ceremony in 2020. On Saturday night at the Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse in Cleveland, where the organization’s museum is based, the event returned with a powerful lineup to laud its 36th annual class: a former United States president, Taylor Swift and a Beatle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Late Homers Have Atlanta on the Cusp of a Championship
description: Atlanta shocked Houston with back-to-back homers in the seventh inning, putting the team one win from its first World Series title since 1995.
content: ATLANTA — Dansby Swanson held his right arm in the air as he floated around the bases. Excitement had been slowly building through the night as a sleepy Atlanta Braves lineup started to wake up. But after Swanson’s game-tying home run clanked off the right field wall in the seventh inning of Game 4 of the World Series, Truist Park erupted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Jason Horowitz and Jim Tankersley
title: G20 Nations Agree to New Limits on Coal-Burning Power Plants
description: The world’s largest economies will stop financing coal plants abroad, though that falls far short of what’s needed to fight climate change, raising fears of half-steps at this week’s U.N. summit.
content: GLASGOW — Having powered the industrial era, coal made many of the Group of 20 countries what they are today: the world’s 20 largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: What if Everything You Learned About Human History Is Wrong?
description: In “The Dawn of Everything,” the anthropologist David Graeber and the archaeologist David Wengrow aim to rewrite the story of our shared past — and future.
content: One August night in 2020, David Graeber — the anthropologist and anarchist activist who became famous as an early organizer of Occupy Wall Street — took to Twitter to make a modest announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: At Saudi Investment Conference, Trump Allies Remain Front and Center
description: But the Biden administration sent only a deputy commerce secretary to the high-profile gathering, amid shifts in global politics and diplomatic strains.
content: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The wealthy and the powerful of the financial world descended on the Ritz-Carlton in Riyadh this past week for Saudi Arabia’s annual investment conference, a reminder that even amid shifting politics, diplomatic strains and pandemic constraints, money is a surefire magnet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Saying Yes to Baseball Meant Leaving Football Behind
description: Austin Riley was a quarterback and all-state punter in high school, but baseball was his true love. His breakout season helped power Atlanta’s surge to the World Series.
content: ATLANTA — When Atlanta seized a three-games-to-one lead over Houston, the team had plenty of hang time while attempting to win its first World Series since 1995. So it makes sense that the team’s newest star was an all-state punter in high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: 5,000 Shows Later, the Grand Ole Opry Is Still the Sound of Nashville
description: A two-hour celebration for the milestone broadcast captured the shifts and strides in country music that played out over the past century on the Opry stage.
content: NASHVILLE — The survival of the Grand Ole Opry was anything but guaranteed when Bill Anderson started performing in it six decades ago. Rock ’n’ roll was luring away fans. Radio stations were abandoning barn dance-style programs. There were nights, he said, when musicians could look out from the Opry stage and see empty seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: He Brokered Apartheid’s End. Can He Save South Africa’s Liberation Party?
description: President Cyril Ramaphosa ascended to office on a reputation as a great negotiator and consensus builder. Now he must convince voters to stick with the party of Nelson Mandela.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The motorcade of black luxury vehicles carrying President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa rumbled through the narrow township streets, swerved around potholes filled with stale water from backed-up drainage ditches and stopped near the concrete shell of an unfinished government-supplied house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 1, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Police Struggle to Curb Abuse of Women by Their Own Officers
description: Sexual misconduct by police officers has prompted outrage across Britain and led to increasing skepticism that departments can investigate or discipline employees who abuse women.
content: LONDON — James Mason was on duty in a North London police station when a young woman came in to report that she had just been mugged on a city street. Already shaken, the woman became even more unnerved by Mr. Mason’s questions: What clothes did she wear to work? Did she have a boyfriend? Would she like to go to dinner?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, C.J. Chivers and Elisheba Ittoop
title: The Sunday Read: “Fear on Cape Cod as Sharks Hunt Again”
description: The apex predator is back along New England’s beaches. What will it take to keep people safe?
content: Over the past decade, the waters around Cape Cod have become host to one of the densest seasonal concentrations of adult white sharks in the world. Acoustic tagging data suggest the animals trickle into the region during lengthening days in May, increase in abundance throughout summer, peak in October and mostly depart by Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire and Michael H. Keller
title: The Demand for Money Behind Many Police Traffic Stops
description: Busted taillights, missing plates, tinted windows: Across the U.S., ticket revenue funds towns — and the police responsible for finding violations.
content: Harold Brown’s contribution to the local treasury began as so many others have in Valley Brook, Okla.: A police officer saw that the light above his license plate was out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Parker
title: What Happens When Everyone Is Writing the Same Book You Are?
description: Olivia Parker was intrigued by the tale of her great-great-uncle’s failed quest to unearth a holy relic. Then she discovered that six other writers were also pursuing the story.
content: It was as if the story were floating in the air, waiting to be rediscovered. And by coincidence, a handful of writers came across it at the same time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 31, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 31, 2021.
content: The Weekend Arts section on Friday omitted the byline of the critic who wrote the Tribeca Gallery Guide overview. He is Will Heinrich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: We Remember Saints Because They’re a Lot Like Us
description: All Saints’ Day reminds us that faith is shaped by our relationships with other people.
content: Most major Christian holidays focus on an event in the life of Jesus, but All Saints’ Day, which falls on Nov. 1, is fixed on stories of his people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Climate conference begins in Glasgow.
content: Presidents and prime ministers are gathering in Glasgow this week to discuss global climate policies, which are likely to determine the future of the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Learning to Live With Mark Zuckerberg
description: Journalists and tech executives seem to be fighting each other to a draw in a battle that has no end in sight.
content: After Mark Zuckerberg announced, in a goofy video on Thursday, that he was changing his company’s name to Meta and shifting its focus to the creation of a digital space called the metaverse, he granted interviews to just four media outlets, including exactly zero of the great American legacy publications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Jason Horowitz
title: G20 leaders send a symbolic message on a key climate target.
description: Countries will “pursue efforts” to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared with preindustrial times.
content: Leaders of the Group of 20 nations sent a symbolic message on Sunday as one of the most important climate conferences began, pledging to “pursue efforts” to keep the average global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius by the end of this century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Immigration Detainees Are Owed $17 Million in Back Pay, Jury Says
description: The detainees had been working for $1 a day in a for-profit detention center in Tacoma, Wash., a labor practice that a federal jury said violated state law.
content: A federal jury in Washington State has found that the operator of a for-profit detention center in Tacoma owed $17.3 million in back pay to immigration detainees who were denied minimum wage for the work they performed there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Advice You Don’t Need, but Might Want
description: The Tip column in The New York Times Magazine draws meaningful lessons from unlikely situations.
content: Malia Wollan is not out to scold you about your table manners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Matthew Cullen
title: In the Final Days Before Virginia Votes, Both Sides Claim Momentum
description: Glenn Youngkin and Terry McAuliffe crisscrossed Virginia on the last weekend of what has become an increasingly close race for governor.
content: MANASSAS PARK, Va. — The high-stakes race for governor of Virginia entered its final stretch with Glenn Youngkin and Terry McAuliffe trading accusations of sowing division, as voters appeared closely divided over returning a Democrat to office or electing a Republican to lead their state for the first time in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Pulled Over: What to Know About Deadly Police Traffic Stops
description: A New York Times investigation examines why traffic stops can escalate into fatal encounters and how hidden financial incentives increase the risks. This is what we found.
content: When Daunte Wright was killed last spring by a police officer in Minnesota after being pulled over for expired registration tags, the case drew national attention. So have several other seemingly avoidable deaths of motorists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Jerry Remy, Red Sox Player and Longtime Commentator, Dies at 68
description: An All-Star second baseman, he spent 34 years as a broadcast analyst and was voted the first president of Red Sox Nation by fans.
content: Jerry Remy, the Boston Red Sox second baseman who became a fan favorite of Red Sox Nation as the team’s broadcast analyst for the last 34 years, died on Saturday. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: The Places in New York City Where Republicans Still Stand a Chance
description: In some New York City Council races, supporting former President Donald Trump is seen as a positive by voters.
content: For most Democratic candidates running in New York City, criticizing former President Donald J. Trump hardly requires making a studied campaign strategy decision — it’s already a given.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan
title: Afghan Art Flourished for 20 Years. Can It Survive the New Taliban Regime?
description: So far, the Taliban have not banned art outright. But many artists have fled Afghanistan, fearing for their work and their lives.
content: The day Afghanistan’s president, Ashraf Ghani, fled and handed the country over to the Taliban, Omaid Sharifi was in downtown Kabul, helping his colleagues paint murals on the wall of the governor’s office. By noon, panicked employees in nearby government buildings were flooding the streets, some jumping into cars, others pedaling bicycles or running to get home, or to the airport.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Colossal Stakes as Leaders Meet to Talk Climate
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 31, 2021.
content: “We’ve just experienced the worst part of humanity’s response to a global crisis. And if this is going to be the track record for addressing the global climate crisis, then we are in trouble. I’m hoping this is a moment of reflection and inflection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Atlanta Is Peaking at Exactly the Right Time
description: An 88-win team faced a series of daunting challenges, yet is on the verge of a championship thanks to timely hitting and terrific bullpen work.
content: ATLANTA — In a sport that revels in the unpredictable, the Atlanta Braves were once a sure thing. With almost ruthless efficiency, they won their division 14 times in a row, a streak that began before Dansby Swanson was born and ended when he was almost a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: The Last Words of Rachel Held Evans
description: She gave voice to a generation of wandering evangelicals wrestling with their faith. Two years after her sudden death at age 37, Rachel Held Evans has one more message.
content: Two years ago, the sudden death of Rachel Held Evans at age 37 left a community of spiritual seekers in shock and heartbreak. A best-selling author and provocative thinker, Ms. Evans and her work had offered a home for a diaspora of believers wrestling with evangelical Christianity, a community yearning to seek God, find safety amid doubt, and include those whom the churches of their youth had rejected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Jim Tankersley and Coral Davenport
title: At Climate Talks, Biden Will Try to Sell American Leadership to Skeptics
description: The president wants to assure Glasgow’s climate summit that the U.S. is serious about climate change. But he lacks a legislative win at home.
content: GLASGOW — President Biden will walk into a riverside event space on Monday to try to convince a gathering of world leaders that the United States, which has pumped more greenhouse gases into the atmosphere than any other nation, is finally serious about addressing climate change and that others should follow its lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The F.D.A. is assessing whether the Moderna vaccine can cause heart problems in adolescents.
description: The F.D.A. has notified Moderna that it needs more time to review the vaccine’s safety and may not deliver a decision until January.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is reviewing reports suggesting the coronavirus vaccine made by Moderna can cause heart problems in some adolescents, the company said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Chris Cameron
title: What to Watch in the Supreme Court Oral Arguments on the Texas Abortion Law
description: The New York Times will be streaming the oral arguments and providing live coverage of the proceedings when they begin at 10 a.m. Eastern.
content: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Monday in two challenges to a Texas law that bars most abortions in the state after six weeks of pregnancy. The justices will consider whether abortion providers in the state and the Biden administration are entitled to challenge the law, which was intended to evade review in federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Brazilian Police Kill 25 Accused of Planning Bank Heists
description: The police say an operation against a gang planning bank robberies killed at least 25 suspects in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais on Sunday.
content: BRASÍLIA — The police say an operation against a gang planning bank robberies killed at least 25 suspects in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Parmet
title: A Dangerous Legal Battle Over Vaccine Mandates Will Continue
description: The Supreme Court is welcoming a legal battle with far-reaching implications.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to allow Maine’s vaccine mandate for health care workers to go into effect was an important victory for efforts to control the pandemic through vaccination. But it is not a final one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 8 in the N.F.L.
description: The Saints' defense stepped up when Jameis Winston went down, Josh Allen shook off an uncharacteristically sloppy start, and wide receivers around the league auditioned for Tuesday’s trade deadline.
content: They’ve been banging at the Super Bowl door for half a decade. They’ve had their collective hearts ripped out in new inconceivable ways each January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: 125 Years After the First College Golf Match, a Rematch
description: Intercollegiate golf was born in 1896 when Yale thrashed Columbia with mashies and niblicks. Armed with titanium drivers, Columbia sought revenge.
content: On a fall day in 1896, a group of Yale students, caught up in a new sports craze called golf, traveled from their New Haven, Conn., campus by train and stagecoach to a course north of New York City — one of the few clubs in the country at the time — to take on some chaps from Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Hisako Ueno and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan’s Election Was Closer Than Usual, Even Though Party in Power Has Hit Snooze
description: The governing Liberal Democrats won on Sunday, despite having chosen a prime minister, Fumio Kishida, who’s known for his lack of charisma.
content: TOKYO — Japan has had no shortage of faceless prime ministers over the decades, a revolving door of leaders forgotten nearly as soon as they leave office. The most recent to hit the exit, who himself lasted only a year, was faulted for a communication style that often came across like a cure for insomnia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon
title: Jets’ Win Raises a Question: Who Is Mike White?
description: Are the Jets watchable yet? They’re starting to get interesting with an upset win and the makings of a quarterback competition.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Gillis
title: Will Glasgow Be the Climate Breakthrough We Need?
description: Time  is running out for the nations of the world to get control of their emissions.
content: The jawboning has been going on for nearly a third of a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: New York’s Irish Arts Center Upgrades to a ‘Flagship Hub’
description: The $60 million building in Hell’s Kitchen, which will present theater, dance, music and more, is scheduled to open in December.
content: Irish Arts Center, a New York nonprofit devoted to championing the culture of Ireland and Irish Americans, is finally moving into a home as big as its aspirations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Subtropical Storm Wanda Forms, Exhausting the List of Names
description: The storm, which was about 900 miles west of the Azores, was not expected to pose any danger to land, the National Hurricane Center said on Sunday.
content: For the second time in two years, and only the third time in history, meteorologists have exhausted the list of names used to identify storms during the Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, has tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: The White House press secretary was vaccinated against Covid when she became infected with the coronavirus.
content: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary who earlier in the week said that she would not join President Biden on a diplomatic trip to Europe because of a family emergency, said on Sunday that she tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: One Dead After Dozens Try to Swim Around San Diego Border Fence
description: As many as 70 swimmers tried to make the crossing from Tijuana, the U.S. authorities said. Thirty-six people were detained.
content: One woman died and 36 people were detained after as many as 70 people tried to swim around a fence that juts into the Pacific Ocean at the border of the United States and Mexico, the authorities said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oxford’s 2021 Word of the Year Is a Shot in the Arm
description: Amid an explosion of Covid-related wordplay, the publisher of the Oxford English Dictionary crowns “vax.”
content: Apologies to jab, shot and “Fauci ouchie.” Oxford Languages’s 2021 Word of the Year is “vax.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger
title: Rivals on World Stage, Russia and U.S. Quietly Seek Areas of Accord
description: There have been a series of beneath-the-surface meetings between the two countries as the Biden administration applies a more sober approach to relations with the Kremlin.
content: MOSCOW — It might seem as if little has changed for Russia and the United States, two old adversaries seeking to undercut each other around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: “Vax” is Oxford’s 2021 word of the year.
description: Apologies to jab, shot and “Fauci ouchie.” Oxford Languages’s 2021 Word of the Year is “vax.”
content: Apologies to jab, shot and “Fauci ouchie.” Oxford Languages’s 2021 Word of the Year is “vax.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: From Facebook to Meta
description: Last week, Tesla reached a $1 trillion market valuation, a milestone that has only been passed by five other companies. This week: The Fed may announce plans to start to taper its bond purchases.
content: Last week, more than a dozen news organizations published reports based on a trove of Facebook’s internal documents leaked by a former product manager. The documents detail what Facebook knew about its role in radicalizing users, employees’ questions about the impact of its core features, and its struggles to curb dangerous content internationally. The former Facebook employee-turned-whistle-blower, Frances Haugen, has appeared on “60 Minutes,” in front of Congress, and — this past week — in Britain’s Parliament to argue that the company puts profits before people. (Facebook has said that it has millions of documents that counter those shared by Ms. Haugen). Whistle-blowers have filed at least nine complaints against Facebook with the Securities and Exchange Commission based on internal documents. On Thursday, Facebook changed its name to Meta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Aramco reports a $30 billion quarterly profit as oil prices soar.
description: Earnings nearly tripled, showing that oil retains a large role in the global economy despite climate change concerns.
content: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said Sunday that its profits for the third quarter nearly tripled compared with the period a year earlier, as demand for the fuel recovers from the pandemic and prices soar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: China’s Popular Electric Vehicles Have Put Europe’s Automakers on Notice
description: By selling battery-powered S.U.V.s and luxury sedans in places like Germany and Norway, China is striving to become a force in the global auto industry.
content: FRANKFURT — The name MG used to be synonymous with spirited but finicky sports cars from Britain. Nowadays the iconic octagonal badge serves a different kind of motoring ambition: China’s push to become a big player in the global auto market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Angling for a Merry ‘Fishmas’ Despite Global Shipping Delays
description: The travails of a Chicago fishing company’s advent calendar highlight the supply chain hurdles for businesses trying to deliver items in time for the holidays.
content: WASHINGTON — It was 73 days until Christmas, and the clock was ticking down for Catch Co.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Drug Boss Alpo Martinez Killed in Harlem
description: Mr. Martinez, 55, who was immortalized in the film “Paid in Full,” played a prominent role in New York’s violent cocaine wars of decades past.
content: Alberto (Alpo) Martinez, whose cocaine-dealing empire stretched from New York to Washington, D.C., at the height of bloody drug turf wars three decades ago, was shot and killed in Harlem early Sunday, according to a high-ranking police official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Kyle Rittenhouse’s Homicide Trial Will Be a Debate Over Self-Defense
description: Mr. Rittenhouse was 17 when he went to Kenosha, Wis., amid protests against police violence. He fatally shot two men and wounded another who were pursuing him.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — After more than a year, Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager from Illinois who has been labeled by some as a defender of law and order and by others as a reckless gunman, is set to stand trial on charges of homicide in a Wisconsin courtroom starting on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Former Shoe Shiner Wins Back Nearly $30,000 Seized by Federal Agents
description: Authorities at an airport last year seized a bag of cash that Kermit Warren was carrying to buy a truck. It was his life’s savings but prosecutors contended the money was linked to drugs.
content: When Kermit Warren lost his job shining shoes during the Covid-19 pandemic last year, he and his son took his life savings of nearly $30,000 to buy a tow truck to support Mr. Warren’s longtime side business of collecting scrap metal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Steve Eder, Kim Barker and Julie Tate
title: Why Many Police Traffic Stops Turn Deadly
description: Officers, trained to presume danger, have reacted with outsize aggression. For hundreds of unarmed drivers, the consequences have been fatal.
content: “Open the door now, you are going to get shot!” an officer in Rock Falls, Ill., shouted at Nathaniel Edwards after a car chase.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was a Quiet Weekend Afternoon and Not Many People Were Around’
description: A pause on Riverside Drive, watching faraway figures come to life and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Roblox Goes Down, Forcing Children Outside for Halloween
description: After three days offline, the popular gaming site said Sunday that it was back. In the meantime, children were freaking out.
content: This weekend, children around the country began acting strange, as though they were emerging from a trance. They moped around their houses. They started hanging out with their parents. They powered up long-neglected electronics in search of entertainment. Some even — gasp! — went outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. Military Jury Condemns Terrorist’s Torture and Urges Clemency
description: Seven senior officers rebuked the government’s treatment of an admitted terrorist in a handwritten letter from the jury room at Guantánamo Bay.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In a stark rebuke of the torture carried out by the C.I.A. after the Sept. 11 attacks, seven senior military officers who heard graphic descriptions last week of the brutal treatment of a terrorist while in the agency’s custody wrote a letter calling it “a stain on the moral fiber of America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Ashley Southall
title: New York City firefighters are calling out sick as a vaccine mandate looms.
description: More than 22,000 municipal workers remained unvaccinated a day before a city deadline to get their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.
content: More than 2,000 New York City firefighters have taken sick days over the past week in what city officials describe as a large-scale protest against the city’s Covid vaccine mandate for municipal workers, which goes into effect Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: American Airlines Cancels Hundreds of Flights This Weekend
description: The carrier blamed bad weather and staffing shortages. It was the second airline this month to face significant disruptions.
content: American Airlines canceled more than 1,200 flights this weekend, blaming bad weather and staffing shortages for the widespread disruption. The cancellations represented more than 12 percent of the airline’s scheduled flights for Saturday and Sunday, it said, and came just weeks after Southwest Airlines was forced to cancel nearly 2,000 flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $650,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Why Paid Family Leave’s Demise This Time Could Fuel It Later
description: In failing to secure a benefit with bipartisan appeal, President Biden joins a long line of frustrated politicians. But some Republicans say it could be resurrected on its own.
content: WASHINGTON — In late 2019, with bipartisan backing, including from the iconoclastic Senate Democrat Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, President Donald J. Trump’s daughter Ivanka hosted a summit at the White House to promote her vision for paid family and medical leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: ‘Caws’ for Concern
description: Fiona Taylor is your Monday morning quarterback.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Fiona Taylor, who is making her New York Times Crossword debut with this day-after-Halloween puzzle. I hope you all enjoyed the holiday and saw many children dressed in 19th-century garb like the two young scamps in the picture above. Or, you know, “Avengers” costumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael H. Keller, Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick, Kim Barker, Julie Tate and Mike McIntire
title: By the Numbers: Police Traffic Stops
description: My colleagues and I published an investigation into police traffic stops: how and why they escalate into violence, and the financial incentives fueling it all.
content: My colleagues and I published an investigation into police traffic stops: how and why they escalate into violence, and the financial incentives fueling it all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Handwritten Document
description: This letter was drafted in the deliberation room recommending clemency for Majid Khan. Seven members of Mr. Khan’s eight-officer jury signed it, using their panel numbers. The jury was drawn from a pool of 20 active-duty officers who were brought to Guantánamo Bay on Oct. 27.
content: This letter was drafted in the deliberation room recommending clemency for Majid Khan. Seven members of Mr. Khan’s eight-officer jury signed it, using their panel numbers. The jury was drawn from a pool of 20 active-duty officers who were brought to Guantánamo Bay on Oct. 27.

author: By Robin Stein, Haley Willis, Brenna Smith, Natalie Reneau, Rumsey Taylor, David D. Kirkpatrick, Steve Eder, Kim Barker and Michael Beswetherick
title: Before the Final Frame: When Police Missteps Create Danger
description: A New York Times visual investigation rolled back the footage of fatal traffic stops to examine the causes and the consequences of officer-created jeopardy.
content: A New York Times visual investigation rolled back the footage of fatal traffic stops to examine the causes and the consequences of officer-created jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: Storms Cause Deadly Floods in Sicily
description: Storms brought record rainfall to the southern region of the Italian island and killed three people around the city of Catania.
content: Storms brought record rainfall to the southern region of the Italian island and killed three people around the city of Catania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Farro and cauliflower Parm, and garlic-braised chicken make for great weeknight cooking.
content: Good morning. Happy Halloween. I’m not much for spooky high jinks, much less candy corn or miniature Milky Ways, but this afternoon I’ll put on my mask to hand out Snickers bars to the little dinosaurs and Ted Lassos all the same, before a dinner of hot-sauce shrimp (above), dirty rice, braised greens and cornbread. We’ll have the last of the holiday candies for dessert, clean up and watch “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times
